keyTakeAways: A high-value jewellery heist at the Louvre in Paris involved four masked thieves who stole items including a Napoleon-era diamond and emerald necklace, a tiara from Empress Eugenie, and other royal pieces.
The stolen items were valued at €88 million by French public prosecutors, highlighting the immense cultural and economic value of France’s heritage.

The thieves used power tools to break through a glass window, threatened guards, and escaped using scooters after attempting to set fire to their truck, indicating high levels of planning and coordination.
Experts believe the stolen jewellery has likely been melted down and sold as scrap, due to the lack of recovery prospects and the rapid nature of the theft.
Security flaws were exposed, including missing CCTV in one in three rooms and a failure of the central alarm system, prompting nationwide security upgrades.
French President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin condemned the attack as a direct threat to national heritage and a failure in public safety protocols.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A daring daylight heist at the Louvre in Paris saw four masked thieves steal high-value jewellery, including a Napoleon-era necklace and Empress Eugenie’s tiara, valued at €88 million. Using power tools and a modified truck, the thieves breached the museum within minutes of opening, threatening guards and escaping on scooters. Security flaws, including missing CCTV and a failed alarm system, were identified, prompting national security reviews. Experts believe the stolen items have likely been melted and sold abroad, with little chance of recovery. French officials, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as a devastating blow to national heritage and a failure of public safety.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
